topic.title: Lets fix ZeroNet
topic.body:
I'm tired as fuck of not being able to generate IDs using Tor. We need a truly decentralized system for certificate generation.
For this we'll need a web of trust system so peers can verify each other in a trustful way and not rely on a few centralized nodes to do the certificate generation like KXoID does (which btw currently means XKoID does not work most of the time because no trusted peers are online).
This is the way I envision the system working:
Using the new one click plugin installation functionality, a user installs a plugin that monkey patches ZeroNet to achieve all the required functionality.
The plugin includes a few trusted peers and provides the user the ability to include more or remove the existing ones.
If the user is a trusted peer (either a root one or further down the chain) it receives requests from other users (maybe through PeerMessage?) to either generate certificates or become trusted (they probably should be different things to have different degrees of trustfulness to generate certs or become a generator of certs).
Now, the thing is, every peer using the system needs to receive a copy of the web of trust chain from the root to the node that's generating whatever content is being received by said peer.
I guess this could be implemented on top of PGP, but I'm not sure how easy it would be to implement a key server on ZeroNet. I think this would depend on how easy it'd be to run OpenPGP HTTP Keyserver Protocol (HKP) over PeerMessage or whatever is used. Although I guess we could just use clearnet key servers for simplicity. Care should be taken to only choose servers hardened against key poisoning. So when a peer becomes trusted a public key is uploaded, and when a peer sees content coming from a previously non seen pair a key chain is downloaded.
The difference with simpler certificate authorities like KaffieID is this thing would be able to impose restrictions on name generation. If a trusted node becomes rogue and starts generating bogus IDs or trust certificates, it could be blacklisted individually by the users, or more effectively by a distributed node blacklist all users are subscribed to by default. The details on what peers would be able to add nodes to the blacklist are yet to be determined, but presumably this would be based on some kind of computed trustworthiness level.
The way a node gets an ID would be by completing a captcha and a light PoW. The way a node becomes trusted would be by completing a captcha, having a high seed value and file availability, and completing a harder PoW challenge. The node ID would probably have to be different from the user ID so people are able to become trusted nodes without having to post using the same ID all the time.

1570109199_1N4DSSHorDvEkDGkQfUhnnryYiTdt.body:
> [stardust666](#comment_2_16Fu36vdXG8dynYf9XUqN9F1za5xa19gHK): I don't use TOR. Doesn't ZeroID allow you to generate a certificate through TOR? That's weird.
It only works with Tor like 1 out of 5 times. It used to work almost always until nofish made some changes to prevent automatic generation of IDs based on banning certain IPs depending on undisclosed criteria (current version of ZeroID is proprietary).
>Since certificates are just a mapping of names to public keys, couldn't we just use the Namecoin blockchain?
It's a bit more complicated than that. The point of certificates is that only trusted parties (certificate authorities) are allowed to map names to keys. Then the dilemma is who becomes that trusted party, since can easily become a gatekeeper and prevent people from generating certs for one reason or another, like ZeroID does with Tor, or they can just go down and then nobody is able to generate certs (like with KXoID).

> [gitcenter](#comment_1122_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): You can't implement that without rethinking usernames from the beginning. Currently there's no way to revoke a username - once you register it for a user you can't cancel.

I know all of this would require pretty big changes to the ZeroNet code (whether through a plugin or a fork). The only way for people using the current ZeroNet client to see the messages posted by people using this web of trust system would be to at least re-register every user using a conventional CA, assuming the actual protocol for exchanging data stays the same (I don't see a priori any reason why it would have to be changed).

> [gitcenter](#comment_1122_1Cy3ntkN2GN9MH6EaW6eHpi4YoRS2nK5Di): You can't implement that without rethinking usernames from the beginning. Currently there's no way to revoke a username - once you register it for a user you can't cancel.

Btw, as the system currently works, can a CA just decide to register a user and that certificate be accepted by sites (even for old posts) with no intervention from the user? You seemed to imply that was the case when explaining what would be done if the private key for KXoID was leaked, but I don't know how that would work. Or were you just saying the key would be changed but the posts made by users certified with the old key would be lost?

> [fartknocker](#comment_18_19s8EgXft8KuYsk9tEGgnmLo3Kcmw3ME5E): It's a decent idea, but in practice it could cripple the system. You go one way and just take a look at RetroShare. Ever used it? It's like taking a shot in the dark at random people you may or may not know. It's an even gayer version of Utopia (which is still in Beta). [...]

I haven't used it, but from reading about it I don't see any similarities with what I'm proposing.
>The flip side is majority rule over what sites are allowed.
You could make the blacklist be dictated by a single person (in fact it would be easier to do that way). It's an implementation detail that is yet to be determined.
It would be better if it was possible for the blacklist to determine who can generate IDs and not what IDs can be used (after they were generated) but the problem is I don't see an easy way to decouple both things. Maybe you could make it so other trusted peers are required to certify users with a given timestamp, and once you have that temporal variable established you can allow people who created their ID before the node ban was established to continue posting with their ID as long as the timestamp was provided by non banned nodes (or their descendants which are presumably banned by proxy). Or maybe you could make it so users just need to re-certify their user and upload that new signature to the key server, and upon stumbling on users with an ID certified by a banned CA, double check their authenticity by re-downloading the certificate chain from the key server. I don't know how capable PGP is in that regard (having multiple endorsement from other users) but it probably supports it.
I realize the complexity of this distributed system is very high and it might be hard to make it work in practice, but I think it's worth a try.

1570458113_14HL4TtDqn72eNpfEQE5WSYjRsYDr.body:
Depends on how much intermodulation products your amp has. If it was just about the amp, it'd probably work. But running them all through a single filter... I don't know, square waves have lots of harmonics. Signals would probably interfere one another.
You could use an fl2k dongle, but the output is only about 2 miliwatts so you'd need another amp stage and you would have to write the software to synthesize the RF signal yourself. Somebody else has done it for AM already though.
Also consider that if you ran a single FM station, probably nobody would give a shit. But occupying multiple slots in the FM band, I don't know man. Probably nothing would happen, but you never know.

> [zenanon](#comment_29_14kTJXu4KZSoWSSNcGtXEijf4NqEGimc9J): Tor was an intelligence project from the inception. This was never secret. "Our" glowniggers needed to hide from their glowniggers. So glowniggers had to build a glownigger proof system that was useful enough that lots of non-glowniggers would use it...for deniability.

Because nobody ever devised a system where only one party is able to break its security...
In any case, this is a misconception. The purpose of Tor is doing online intelligence and counter-intelligence work. CIA agents don't use Tor when working in the field, at least I haven't seen any evidence they do. From the released info I've heard about they seem to just use burner phones and in person meetings.

And BTW I don't think there's anything incriminating in those files. The most talked about thing that was going around was a mail of the BBG asking when "SSL normalization" was going to be completed. SSL normalization means Tor connections look to an observer like a regular HTTPS connection, which is a good thing, but it's not essential.
Another thing that was going around was a supposed leak from an Army employee showing a memo saying they broke Tor. But considering the guy who posted the picture left his name visible, I think it's safe to assume it's a psyop and he only left his name visible so other government employees can call him to find out what's going on and don't freak out thinking it was an actual leak.

> [xcape2net](#comment_446_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Tell me if this makes sense.  There are 900 MHz modems available that are in or near the "citizen's radio band"  in the United States.  They cost about 150 USD.  They should have a range of about 10 km or so.  Essentially no one uses them because WiFi has caught on with the general population, so no one is seriously looking for an alternative.  Plus, there would be a problem using this in a city with millions of other people using them.  But they should work just fine for a location where there are 10-20 other people using them within range.  There should be other similar frequencies that are relatively easy to get licenses for in other countries.  It should be relatively easy to connect a computer running ZeroNet to a 900 Mhz modem and have a stand-alone, 900-MHz-radio-linked ZeroNet network.    [...]

Things like LoRa are extremely low bandwidth. They are for a "send a temperature and voltage reading every 5 minutes" kind of thing, not general TCP/IP networking. 900MHz isn't citizen's band btw. It's an ISM band.

> [xcape2net](#comment_449_1GJc2vm4vJjAKsFoFJ2D3gGmKiRac2kfnz): Makes sense.  So, it would only be good for text-based communication, like email and ZeroTalk.  :)

Maybe. It could be good enough for that depending on how good the signal is. If the signal is bad you'll have to wait half an hour or more to get a full page of text. You cold make small battery powered routers and hide them around in the city.  But still range is not enough to work outside the city. For that you need to go on HF at a frequency lower than about 20Mhz because then it reflects off the ionosphere and you can get out thousands of miles on little power. But then you need a ham radio license and can only run one transmitter at a time. There's a small ISM band at 13Mhz but  the power limits are tiny.
